You know that moment and you're just getting to know someone at all of a sudden they say that one thing but it totally changes the way you see them well sometimes I think you know turned your way but sometimes applause you when I was with this story from the writer to ...
I met a man from Long Island and at a bar by chance a year after I moved to New York and right away I liked him we walked from the bar
To a twenty four hour diner in the East Village and got grilled cheese sandwiches and French fries and drank bad room temperature coffee and talked for hours until a stranger came over and asked if we can to officiate our wedding right there at the sticky table by the bathroom
By then it was light outside
I'd known to man for nine hours and I was powered by an engine of pure enthusiasm
I said sure why not yes
I waitress rolled her eyes but agreed to be the witness at least near an unofficial document with catch
Not long after I learned that the man I diner married had worked for many years opening clams and oysters in bars and it had left him with a calm clear eyed appreciation what I mean is he didn't get worked up when he talked about a wasters not like some people I knew
He didn't insist that I Try one particular variety grown off one remote island with nothing but a square as Lehman because anything more would be disrespectful to the oyster
I liked to history is just fine but not that much when I eat them raw by the death and they were occasionally delicious fat an intact and salty slipping out of pristine shelves just as often they were nothing special
Like mouthful just land brackish jelly or the sled off coins from deep pockets or the fermented milk mythical sea creature they didn't seem worth the hassle
But there was something about the way he liked oysters keenly and quietly without fetish or hyperbole that made me reconsider we carried a hundred along with a jar of chopped Charlotte's and vinegar to my friend's apartment one New Year's eve
We ate them smoked on crackers and hot and pan rest and when we visited friends in New Orleans roasted and garlic butter Frankel with pulverized anchovies on cayenne pepper then we walked down the street with grease stains on our clothes toward music
When my parents came to visit the apartment we shared I blitz butter and a food processor with hot sauce lemon zest and garlic he sat at the table outside and talked an open oysters with them while I let the charcoal from my tiny travel size grill
It took a few minutes for the butter to start bubbling to make a tank ... with the oyster liquor and for the meat to heat through then we ate and rounds putting a dozen or so have shells on the grill every time we ran out
What my mother wanted to know after we'd empty the bottle of wine was if he and I ever talked about getting married not that she reminded us living together no it wasn't that
Not that mattered these days not at all [noise] she wasn't old fashioned she insisted that it would be so nice to know more about my long term plan
I told her the truth that I didn't have any long term plans but that's always turns on the grill couldn't wait

Emergency and because of that other really important stories often get overlooked so every week we take a few minutes to focus in on one story that didn't get that much attention this week and she knew that we always have NPR's Ron Elving
All around good to be with you Scott ... everything else that happened this week President Trump signed a sweeping legislation on Wednesday to address the opioid crisis uh what what was in that bill
A rare moment of bipartisanship actually a piece of legislation aimed at helping people preventing overcome addictions in what has become forest health crisis in this country and many years and you know it's hard to think of another domestic issue where President Obama pushed for legislation and provided funding and President Trump has followed up doing more of same
Are reminder on the figures last year more than Seventy thousand Americans died from a drug overdose opioids were responsible for about two thirds of those deaths
That's more than a hundred and Fifteen Americans a day who die from opioids
So the house and Senate passed an opioid bill with near unanimous approval several weeks ago but it was not actually signed into law until this week signed at the White House
Together and we're going to end the ... of drug addiction in America we're going to end it or we're going to at least make an extremely big dent in this terrible terrible problem
So what are some specific things that this law does
One of the factors cited in recent successes with controlling this scourge
Has been access to Medicaid coverage
Which was expanded under the Affordable CARE Act states taking advantage of that have seen some progress in reaching difficult cases among the poor so one of the things this bill does is to lift certain restrictions on the use of Medicaid and Medicare coverage to deal with opioid addiction at backs the creation of comprehensive opioid
Covering centers tries to address the over prescription of opioids and in many doctors appear to be getting the message on this
Uh the new law also backs government research into non addictive drugs that could be used as alternatives for pain management alternative therapies additional measures including new enforcements drinks for the United States Postal service so that they can try to curtail some of these foreign shipments of illegal drugs into the United states
You mentioned some of the overwhelming statistics of of how many people are dying from overdoses I feel like almost every person in the country knows someone in one way or another who struggled with opioids this bill us it signed into law at a time where we're seeing some signs that this crisis may at least be leveling off
Yes that came from Alex Azar the secretary of the department of health and Human Services a data for the first months of twenty Eighteen indicate that the number of opioid deaths is not increasing nearly as fast as in recent years
He used the word slapped and that certainly hopeful term maybe a few percentage points increase this year rather than say ten percent as we saw in the previous year and twenty Seventeen the number of Americans dying from opioids rose to Seventy two thousand from

As fast in the last month to Seventeen and the first few months of twenty Eighteen
So if anything that the government has been doing can further that trend
Of both parties seem to think that's worth doing

Stitching together all these different programs are kind of pastiche of good intentions of that is ultimately not going to be good enough and that that may well be true some people say there needs to be a great deal more money put into all of these programs that it's really just a drop in the bucket against the size of the problem as we've seen
But here again the consensus in the end was let's pass what we can put as many dollars in as we can if we can only agree on that stitched together patchwork programs let's at least to that
That is NPR's Ron Elving every week he catches up on some of the stories that we might have missed thank you Ron thank you Scott
